DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

RBNZ held rates at 1.75%, as expected. The central bank said it sees growth strengthening in the medium-term on the back of accommodative policy, high terms of trade and fiscal spending, although it noted “numerous uncertainties”. RBNZ also commented that the NZD has firmed since November, in part due to a weaker USD and assumed NZD will ease over its forecast horizon. RBNZ Governor Spencer also stated that he is not concerned about NZD, while he also stated that the next rate move could be a hike or cut. (Newswires)

RBI Repo Rate (N/A) 6.00% vs. Exp. 6.00% (Prev. 6.00%). (Newswires)
RBI Reverse Repo Rate (N/A) 5.75% vs. Exp. 5.75% (Prev. 5.75%)
RBI Cash Reserve Ratio (N/A) 4.00% vs. Exp. 4.00% (Prev. 4.00%)

Chinese Foreign Reserves (Jan) USD 3.162tln vs. Exp. USD 3.170tln. (Newswires)

Australian Ambassador Joe Hockey is assisting the Trump Administration with shaping its infrastructure plan. (Fox)


NORTH AMERICA

 

US BUDGET DEAL: Lawmakers have reached a two-year, bipartisan budget deal that will lift government spending by around $300bln, add to the deficit, and raise the debt ceiling through March 2019. The deal still needs to be voted on in the House and the Senate. (Newsiwres)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell announced a US budget deal, while a White House official confirmed that the US congress budget deal is expected to increase spending by about USD 300bln over 2 years and would increase the debt ceiling to March 2019. (Newswires)


Sources stated that the US budget deal would increase non-defence spending by USD 131bln over two years, USD 117bln above Trump's fiscal 2018 budget request, the deal sets USD 20bln over 2 years for infrastructure investments. (Newswires)

 

Fed's Dudley (Voter) said that for now, his economic outlook was unchanged, though a sustained drop in the stock market would impact his outlook, and he stressed that the recent sell off wasn't that a big of a bump.

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter) says that his dissenting vote against a December hike was a close call. He believes the US economy is firing on all cylinders. The Fed can change the pace of its balance sheet runoff if needed, he said, and that the risks seem to be moving towards additional inflation.

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter) said that market corrections are healthy. He is less convinced that higher wages will translate into higher prices, and the Fed is likely to overshoot full employment and that it is wise to remove accommodation but patiently.

US House Financial Services Committee Chair Hensarling said that US wants a strong dollar. (Newswires)

 

 

EU

ECB's Lautenschlaeger stated ECB can stop net QE asset purchases this year, while she also noted that the ECB does not comment on individual fluctuations in the stock market. (Newswires)

ECB'S Nowotny said that the US Treasury is deliberately pressuring the USD & wants to keep it low. (Wiener Zeitung)

Germany's ruling Conservative bloc and the Social Democrats have agreed on forming a coalition government, while there were also reports that SPD’s Schulz is said to step down as leader of the party with Nahles set to replace him. (Newswires)

Some CDU/CSU lawmakers are said to voice concern about a coalition with the SPD. (Newswires)

European Commission's Europe GDP forecast: 2.3% vs Oct 2.1%; 2019 2.0% vs. Oct 1.9%. Inflation forecast: 1.5% vs. Oct 1.4%; 2019 1.6% vs. 1.6%. (Newswires)

Germany's DIHK Chambers of Industry and Commerce raised its 2018 growth forecast to 2.7% (prev. 2.2%) for the German economy. (Newswires)

German Industrial Output MM (Dec) -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. 3.4%). (Newswires)

Spain nominated Economy Minister Luis De Guindos for the role of Vice-President at the ECB, while there were also comments fro, De Guindos does not believe there are asset bubbles forming in Europe due to low rates. (Newswires)


UK

Irish Prime Minister Varadkar reiterated that he supports a two-year Brexit transition period. (Newswires)


FX

The Dollar Index strengthened on Wednesday, rising above the 90-handle. The dollar has found buying interest on safe-haven demand in recent days, though on Wednesday, it seemed to be more a function of tracking yields higher.

The yen and swissy were sold, with USDJPY rising towards highs of 109.70, while USDCHF breaks through .94 to highs near .9450. And gold eased towards $1312 as haven demand lost its lustre. GBP moved lower on Wednesday, and in absence of specific newsflow, the weakness was attributed to momentum-driven trade. The 1.3850 region acted as support, and cable trades off lows heading into Asia. The NZD dropped to the .7220 mark in wake of the RBNZ’s rate decision, with the central bank standing pat on policy, but noting that some short-term economic weakness was on the cards, and it expects the TWI NZ$ to ease back over its forecast window.

 

COMMODITIES

Crude was trading higher as US traders got to their desks. News the Forties Pipeline was shutdown due to a faulty feed control valve. However, weekly inventory data from the EIA showed stocks building in the week (contrary to the API data released on Tuesday), after which crude slid lower. Additionally, traders continued to cite Tuesday’s EIA, which sees US production continuing to rise through 2018.

 

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks (w/e) 1.895M vs. Exp. 3.189M (Prev. 6.776M); US crude production up 3.35% to 10.25mln bpd.
US EIA Weekly Dist. Stocks (w/e 2nd Feb) 3.926mln vs. Exp. -1.419mln (Prev. -1.940mln)
US EIA Weekly Gasoline Stocks (w/e 2nd Feb) 3.414mln vs. Exp. 0.459mln (Prev. -1.980mln)
US EIA Weekly Crude Cushing (w/e 2nd Feb) -0.711mln (Prev. -2.224mln)
US EIA Weekly Refining Util (w/e 2nd Feb) 4.4% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. -2.8%)

INEOS hopes to restart the Forties pipeline overnight after it revealed that it was closed owing to an unexpected closure of a feed control valve. (Newswires)

Baker Hughes January 2018 rig count: Average US rig count for +7 to 937, International rig count +6 to 960. (Newswires)

Platts Survey: OPEC pumped 32.46mln bpd of crude oil in January, up 60,000 bpd from December, as gains by Saudi Arabia and Nigeria more than offset Venezuela's continued slide. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Tillerson has been talking to Latin American countries about potential US "action" on Venezuelan oil. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

The US Pentagon chief said that the North Korea standoff is 'firmly in the diplomatic lane.’ (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

Equities have clearly shown signs of stabilisation following Monday’s hammering, though the losses from Friday and Monday are yet to be fully pared back. Incidentally, volume in the EMINIS was higher than yesterday’s bounce-back, and as some bank desk noted after the sell-off, there appears to be value in US equities on the back of lower P/E multiples amid the background of solid corporate earnings and a positive US economic backdrop. Meanwhile, the VIX continues to ease back, now knocking around the 25 mark (vs c.30 on Tuesday). On the other hand, some desks have pointed out that investors were concerned about an ‘overstretched’ market before Monday’s sell-off, and traders remain mindful of rising yields and the impending withdrawal of stimulus by central banks (albeit, at a ‘gradual’ pace). In stock specific news, Boeing was an outperformer, after the company noted key issues remain regarding Embraer (ERJ) talks, and separately, it said it is hopeful South Korea will decide on the purchase of P-8 Poseidon maritime patrol aircraft by the year end. Chipotle was a laggard after investors cooled on the restaurant following its earnings. S&P500 -0.50% at 2682, NDX -1.26% at 6582, DJIA -0.10% at 24890.

Top sectors: Telecom +0.3%, Industrials +0.27%, Financials +0.17%
Bottom sectors: Energy -1.67%, IT -1.36% Materials -0.86%

T-Note Futures settled -15+ ticks at 121-00: The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Wednesday, (2s +4.5bps, 5s +6.4bps, 10s +8.5bps, 30s 8.3bps). There was also modest steepening in major curve spreads (2s10s + 2bps, 5s30s +3bps, 2s30s +3bps). A weak 10-year auction, as well as US lawmakers agreeing on a two-year bipartisan budget that would lift caps on government spending – and increase the debt ceiling through March 2019 – were the main drivers.  The US Treasury sold $24bln of 10-year notes, in a soft auction, which tailed by 0.8bps, while cover fell versus the previous auction and recent averages. Dealer participation rose, leaving directs and indirects with a lower takedown. The auction of 10s follows the soft auction of 3s on Tuesday; markets were keeping an eye out to see if current yields are at attractive levels for investors to step in, arresting the sharp rise in yields witnessed recently; however, evidence of this remains to be seen. In wake of today’s auction, the curve continued to sell-off, with 10s hitting 2.85% shortly afterwards.

subject: PREVIEW: RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision & Monetary Policy Statement Due At 20:00 GMT On Wednesday 7th February 2018, Press Conference Due At 21:00 GMT
content:
All of those surveyed expect the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) to stand pat and leave its Official Cash Rate at 1.75%.

Most believe that interim Governor Grant Spencer will act as a placeholder, before Adrian Orr assumes the role in March. As a result, consensus looks for the Reserve Bank to maintain its balanced assessment and to emphasise that interest rates are likely to remain low for a considerable period of time.

The NZIER Shadow Board has once again recommended that the Reserve Bank should remain on hold with a small tightening bias, although it stressed that there is no urgency to lift the OCR. NZIER’s chief economist stressed that “businesses have become more downbeat about the economy since the new Government took office. Although this pessimism is not reflected in expected demand in their own business, it still suggests the Reserve Bank should allow more time to assess these recent developments before lifting interest rates.”

The recently released Q4 CPI data was perhaps not as weak as the headlines suggested, as the domestic inflationary pressures were more upbeat than the tradeables side of the release which weighed on the headline. Nonetheless, markets reacted to the data pushing out expectations of the first RBNZ rate increase from November 2018 to the first quarter of 2019. At the time of writing OIS are only pricing in 13bps worth of tightening for the reminder of the year (or a little over a 50/50 chance of a hike).

Westpac are more sanguine than the majority, noting that they “have long argued that inflation will prove lower than the RBNZ expects, and continue to forecast OCR hikes only from late-2019.”

The Q4 labour market report proved to be slightly more encouraging than the inflation release at first glance, although it doesn’t seem to have altered the monetary policy outlook for most. Following the release ANZ noted that “the labour market remains strong, but is perhaps showing a few more signs of slowing under its own (capacity-constrained) weight.  But despite this, signs of a sustained lift in wage pressure remain tentative at best. Some wage measures are off their lows, but are hardly lifting in a way that would suggest broader inflation pressures are about to be unleashed. We therefore see little in the figures to alter the RBNZ’s cautious stance towards the monetary policy outlook.”

Westpac struck a similar tone, opining that “However, a broader range of measures suggests that there is still some slack remaining in the labour market. Wage growth remains very subdued, even after accounting for low inflation. There is no urgency for the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates in this environment.”

This decision will be accompanied by the quarterly Monetary Policy Statement (MPS) which will include the latest set of economic forecasts (November’s MPS can be found here).

It is also worth noting that a new Policy Targets Agreement (PTA) is yet to be signed. ASB suggest that “the published forecasts should depict a solid outlook for economic outlook. The low inflation starting point and higher than expected NZD could result in marginal downward tweaks in the published Official Cash Rate profile, but given pending changes in the monetary policy framework, financial markets should tread cautiously on drawing too much into any tweaks.”

What the bank desks are saying: -

ANZ: The RBNZ will again leave the OCR at 1.75%, and retain a cautiously upbeat stance. Developments since the November Statement have been mixed to say the least, but we are not expecting the broad spirit of its assessment to change a great deal. A similar interest rate profile is likely (although at the margin the risks are perhaps that it is a touch lower). The RBNZ is not expecting to have to tighten until the second half of 2019. This is a view we now share.

ASB: On Thursday, the RBNZ delivers its final Monetary Policy Statement, and penultimate Official Cash Rate (OCR) decision under the current Policy Target Agreement. Grant Spencer has been acting Governor since Wheeler’s 5-year term ended in September (just after the General Election). Adrian Orr has subsequently been announced as the new Governor, taking over on March 27th (just days after the March 22nd OCR review). It’s widely expected Adrian Orr will sign a Policy Targets Agreement that incorporates a second target of maximizing employment, alongside price stability. The details of such are yet to be announced. With a change in team, rules and referee taking place at the RBNZ, along with the general consensus that there is no urgency to move rates (see chart of the week), there little need for the RBNZ to offer anything more than an update on where it sees inflationary pressure heading. The published forecasts should depict a solid outlook for economic outlook. A weaker inflation starting point and higher-than-expected NZD could result in marginal downward tweaks in the published OCR profile. However, due to pending changes in the monetary policy framework, financial markets would be best to interpret the rate profile cautiously. One of the key thematics we have been emphasising is interest rate convergence, with rising (but lower) global interest rates converging with upwardly drifting (but higher) NZD rates. While our 1.75% OCR is currently above equivalent policy rates for most OECD comparators, global short-term rates are expected to play catch-up. Current market pricing has close to three Fed hikes fully priced in for 2018, versus our on hold for 2018 OCR view and market pricing of around 15bps of OCR hikes by the end of the year. The removal of policy accommodation is also expected by the ECB and Bank of England, contributing to further compression with NZD rates. Australian short-term rates are also expected to edge up, albeit gradually. To a large extent the expected moves in policy rates have already been “priced in” to the curve, particularly for short-to-medium-term horizons. Viewing wholesale interest rate curves shows that NZD rates are below USD counterparts over the 6-month to the 4-year tenor. This convergence is taking place amid a backdrop of a trend decline in assessments of where policy interest rates will settle in the longer term. Estimates of the neutral NZ policy rate OCR rate at around 3.5% (as compared to 6-7% back in 1999) are only 75 bps above current estimates of where the Fed policy rate will gravitate to in the longer-term. Potential catalysts include the achievement of low inflation and low inflation expectations given disinflation by the RBNZ, weaker productivity growth, a potential “glut” of savings over investment and the likelihood that policy moves have greater traction, due to the climb in indebtedness.

BNZ: At Thursday’s Monetary Policy Statement, we expect the RBNZ will largely stick with the OCR forecasts it had back in November. That is, no full first OCR hike until early 2020. The information flow over the last couple of months might even argue, at the margin, for a softer track. However, this is balanced by 1) the sense there is already a strong precautionary element to the OCR setting, 2) the Bank’s recent emphasis on the flexibility it has in guiding inflation to the mid-point of its target band and 3) the fact there are a number of identifiable inflation impulses on the near horizon. This probably explains why the market is still looking for a first rate hike far earlier than the RBNZ has indicated – albeit that this expectation has drifted out into early 2019, from late 2018. We have also delayed our view on OCR hikes, to a February 2019 start point (while pushing our peak, still 3.00%, out to 2020).

Westpac: We expect the RBNZ to continue with its firmly neutral OCR outlook and repeat its long–held guidance that “Monetary policy will remain accommodative for a considerable period”. Recent developments have been roughly neutral, with low inflation and the high exchange rate counterbalanced by a resurgent housing market and upwardly revised GDP. Foreign exchange markets may react to any comment about the exchange rate being too high, but interest rate markets are unlikely to be perturbed by a steady–as–she–goes MPS.

subject: PREVIEW: RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision & Monetary Policy Statement Due At 20:00 GMT On Wednesday 7th February 2018, Press Conference Due At 21:00 GMT
content:
All of those surveyed expect the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) to stand pat and leave its Official Cash Rate at 1.75%.

Most believe that interim Governor Grant Spencer will act as a placeholder, before Adrian Orr assumes the role in March. As a result, consensus looks for the Reserve Bank to maintain its balanced assessment and to emphasise that interest rates are likely to remain low for a considerable period of time.

The NZIER Shadow Board has once again recommended that the Reserve Bank should remain on hold with a small tightening bias, although it stressed that there is no urgency to lift the OCR. NZIER’s chief economist stressed that “businesses have become more downbeat about the economy since the new Government took office. Although this pessimism is not reflected in expected demand in their own business, it still suggests the Reserve Bank should allow more time to assess these recent developments before lifting interest rates.”

The recently released Q4 CPI data was perhaps not as weak as the headlines suggested, as the domestic inflationary pressures were more upbeat than the tradeables side of the release which weighed on the headline. Nonetheless, markets reacted to the data pushing out expectations of the first RBNZ rate increase from November 2018 to the first quarter of 2019. At the time of writing OIS are only pricing in 13bps worth of tightening for the reminder of the year (or a little over a 50/50 chance of a hike).

Westpac are more sanguine than the majority, noting that they “have long argued that inflation will prove lower than the RBNZ expects, and continue to forecast OCR hikes only from late-2019.”

The Q4 labour market report proved to be slightly more encouraging than the inflation release at first glance, although it doesn’t seem to have altered the monetary policy outlook for most. Following the release ANZ noted that “the labour market remains strong, but is perhaps showing a few more signs of slowing under its own (capacity-constrained) weight.  But despite this, signs of a sustained lift in wage pressure remain tentative at best. Some wage measures are off their lows, but are hardly lifting in a way that would suggest broader inflation pressures are about to be unleashed. We therefore see little in the figures to alter the RBNZ’s cautious stance towards the monetary policy outlook.”

Westpac struck a similar tone, opining that “However, a broader range of measures suggests that there is still some slack remaining in the labour market. Wage growth remains very subdued, even after accounting for low inflation. There is no urgency for the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates in this environment.”

This decision will be accompanied by the quarterly Monetary Policy Statement (MPS) which will include the latest set of economic forecasts (November’s MPS can be found here).

It is also worth noting that a new Policy Targets Agreement (PTA) is yet to be signed. ASB suggest that “the published forecasts should depict a solid outlook for economic outlook. The low inflation starting point and higher than expected NZD could result in marginal downward tweaks in the published Official Cash Rate profile, but given pending changes in the monetary policy framework, financial markets should tread cautiously on drawing too much into any tweaks.”

What the bank desks are saying: -

ANZ: The RBNZ will again leave the OCR at 1.75%, and retain a cautiously upbeat stance. Developments since the November Statement have been mixed to say the least, but we are not expecting the broad spirit of its assessment to change a great deal. A similar interest rate profile is likely (although at the margin the risks are perhaps that it is a touch lower). The RBNZ is not expecting to have to tighten until the second half of 2019. This is a view we now share.

ASB: On Thursday, the RBNZ delivers its final Monetary Policy Statement, and penultimate Official Cash Rate (OCR) decision under the current Policy Target Agreement. Grant Spencer has been acting Governor since Wheeler’s 5-year term ended in September (just after the General Election). Adrian Orr has subsequently been announced as the new Governor, taking over on March 27th (just days after the March 22nd OCR review). It’s widely expected Adrian Orr will sign a Policy Targets Agreement that incorporates a second target of maximizing employment, alongside price stability. The details of such are yet to be announced. With a change in team, rules and referee taking place at the RBNZ, along with the general consensus that there is no urgency to move rates (see chart of the week), there little need for the RBNZ to offer anything more than an update on where it sees inflationary pressure heading. The published forecasts should depict a solid outlook for economic outlook. A weaker inflation starting point and higher-than-expected NZD could result in marginal downward tweaks in the published OCR profile. However, due to pending changes in the monetary policy framework, financial markets would be best to interpret the rate profile cautiously. One of the key thematics we have been emphasising is interest rate convergence, with rising (but lower) global interest rates converging with upwardly drifting (but higher) NZD rates. While our 1.75% OCR is currently above equivalent policy rates for most OECD comparators, global short-term rates are expected to play catch-up. Current market pricing has close to three Fed hikes fully priced in for 2018, versus our on hold for 2018 OCR view and market pricing of around 15bps of OCR hikes by the end of the year. The removal of policy accommodation is also expected by the ECB and Bank of England, contributing to further compression with NZD rates. Australian short-term rates are also expected to edge up, albeit gradually. To a large extent the expected moves in policy rates have already been “priced in” to the curve, particularly for short-to-medium-term horizons. Viewing wholesale interest rate curves shows that NZD rates are below USD counterparts over the 6-month to the 4-year tenor. This convergence is taking place amid a backdrop of a trend decline in assessments of where policy interest rates will settle in the longer term. Estimates of the neutral NZ policy rate OCR rate at around 3.5% (as compared to 6-7% back in 1999) are only 75 bps above current estimates of where the Fed policy rate will gravitate to in the longer-term. Potential catalysts include the achievement of low inflation and low inflation expectations given disinflation by the RBNZ, weaker productivity growth, a potential “glut” of savings over investment and the likelihood that policy moves have greater traction, due to the climb in indebtedness.

BNZ: At Thursday’s Monetary Policy Statement, we expect the RBNZ will largely stick with the OCR forecasts it had back in November. That is, no full first OCR hike until early 2020. The information flow over the last couple of months might even argue, at the margin, for a softer track. However, this is balanced by 1) the sense there is already a strong precautionary element to the OCR setting, 2) the Bank’s recent emphasis on the flexibility it has in guiding inflation to the mid-point of its target band and 3) the fact there are a number of identifiable inflation impulses on the near horizon. This probably explains why the market is still looking for a first rate hike far earlier than the RBNZ has indicated – albeit that this expectation has drifted out into early 2019, from late 2018. We have also delayed our view on OCR hikes, to a February 2019 start point (while pushing our peak, still 3.00%, out to 2020).

Westpac: We expect the RBNZ to continue with its firmly neutral OCR outlook and repeat its long–held guidance that “Monetary policy will remain accommodative for a considerable period”. Recent developments have been roughly neutral, with low inflation and the high exchange rate counterbalanced by a resurgent housing market and upwardly revised GDP. Foreign exchange markets may react to any comment about the exchange rate being too high, but interest rate markets are unlikely to be perturbed by a steady–as–she–goes MPS.

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 24bln in new 10-year notes on 7 February at 1300 ET/1800 GMT
content:
THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY:

The US Treasury will sell USD 68bln of new 3s (USD 28bln, Tuesday), new 10s (USD 24bln, Wednesday), and new 30s (USD 16bln, Thursday). With USD 46.6bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, net supply is seen at USD 21.4bln.

This month’s series of auctions comes at a key inflection point, with bonds selling-off aggressively at the beginning of the year. The 10-year note, for instance, has added c.40bps in 2018, a trend exacerbated by strong US data and hints that the Fed may lift rates more aggressively than anticipated.

10-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW:

Given the recent sell-off along the US curve, markets will be eyeing this week’s series of auctions to determine whether there is demand for US paper at these levels, or whether this week’s ‘stabilisation’ in yields portends a pause before another round of selling.

January’s 10-year note auction was received very well, with solid stop-through as well as cover above recent averages, and the high yield the largest since July 2014.  Fund takedown was the most since October, while foreign participation rose to the highest since March.

The latest positioning data shows dealers have raised positioning in the 7-11yr bucket to $2.1bln, the most since November.

Analysts at Societe Generale say that the 10-year note trades fair on asset swap when compared to the off-the-runs when viewed over the last two auction cycles, though trades cheap on the curve vs 5s and 30s. Meanwhile, the 2s10s spread has widened by over 10bps since the last auction cycle, and benchmark 10s are yielding more than the previous auction’s stop-out rate.

SocGen believes the 10s auction will benefit from cheap valuations, and we will likely see the largest stop-out rate at a 10s auction since January 2014. It also notes that the 10y benchmark is trading negative in repo, indicating the build-up of a short base, which could be a positive going into the auction.

Negatives, the bank argues, include the larger auction size, following the US Treasury’s recent Quarterly funding announcement, increased probability of more Fed rate hikes in 2018 following last week’s stellar Employment Situation Report, as well as compensation inflation picking up.

10-YEAR AUCTION HISTORY (JANUARY AUCTION VS SIX-AUCTION AVERAGE):
- High-yield: 2.579% (vs six-auction average of 2.342%)
- Tail: Stopped-through by 0.5bps (vs six-auction average tail of 0.3bps)
- Bid-to-cover: 2.69x (vs six-auction average of 2.43x)
- Dealers: 22.0% (vs six-auction average of 29.7%)
- Directs: 6.5% (vs six-auction average of 7.1%)
- Indirects: 71.4% (vs six-auction average of 63.2%)

content:
It’s not been plain-sailing or one-way, but the DXY has held above chart supports below the 89.500 mark and is looking to regain momentum along with US/global stocks. Indeed, the Greenback continues to outpace all its G10 counterparts with the exception of the Jpy that was locked between 109.00 buying interest and a hefty 109.30 option expiry (1 bn) after an early dip below the big figure despite persistent cross/Jpy selling orders. Eur/Usd felt the weight of the aforementioned cross (Eur/Jpy) flow and drifted down towards key support and Fibs just ahead of 1.2300, while Sterling was plagued by ongoing UK political-Brexit issues as latest reports suggest the EU may be seeking bigger budget defense contributions, with Cable edging down towards 1.3900 having breached its 1.3958 21 DMA. Usd/Cad did not deviate far from 1.2500 despite better than forecast Canadian building permits, with the 55 DMA at 1.2507 unchallenged ahead of a speech from BoC’s Wilkins on Thursday. Usd/Chf gradually firmed above 0.9400 and is testing strong resistance around 0.9421. Aud/Usd traded mostly at the bottom end of a 0.7900-0.7850 range, while Nzd/Usd lost grip of the 0.7300 handle after shrugging off consensus beating labour and wage outturns as the focus switched to the RBNZ, with options pricing in a 60 pip move on the event – see our preview via the link below

subject: Fixed Income update: some tech supports tried, and others tested
content: The reversal in core bonds has continued in the run up to the Wall Street opening bell, with Bunds and Gilts posting new session lows at 158.24 and 121.56 respectively for losses on the day of 62 and 37 ticks. The former breached near term supports at 158.45 and 158.36 in the process, and next on the radar is 158.01 before the contract base at 157.62. From a fundamental and flow perspective, the 10 year German benchmark is also losing out the periphery amidst a raft of sought after syndications, less hawkish sounding QE views from ECB’s Lautenschlaeger and fiscal pledges from the new German grand coalition. Back to Liffe, Gilts briefly pierced a downside chart level at 121.60, but not convincingly ahead of the BoE and despite another dip in US Treasuries ahead of the 10 year note sale and some bearish option flow (Apr 120-00 puts bought vs 118.50 strike in 6k lots).

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses trade higher across the board as indices attempt to recoup recent losses ahead of the US entrance to market
content:
• European bourses trade higher across the board as indices attempt to recoup recent losses ahead of the US entrance to market

  • In politics, US House passed bill to fund government through to March 23rd. Germany's Conservatives and Social Democrats have agreed coalition government deal

  • Looking ahead, highlights include the weekly DoEs and potential Fed’s Kaplan, Dudley, Evans and Williams

    ASIA-PAC

    Asian equity markets were mostly higher as region attempted to track the rebound on Wall St. where stocks found reprieve from the 2-day market turmoil on dip buying, which saw S&P 500 briefly reclaim 2700 and the DJIA home in on the 25000 level. ASX 200 (+0.8%) traded positive in which energy and resources names led the recovery as commodities nursed losses, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was initially the best performer and gained over 3% in early-trade before it gradually pared most the advances amid a choppy currency and as momentum waned. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) were both lifted at the open by the early rising tide, although mainland stocks then retreated amid Shenzhen volatility and after the PBoC continued to drain liquidity from the banking system with its inaction. Finally, 10yr JGBs shrugged off the initial safe-haven outflows and returned flat, as price action proved to be as indecisive as the recovery in Japanese stocks. Furthermore, the BoJ’s Rinban announcement failed to spur any market reaction as the bank kept its purchase amounts in line with the previous.

    PBoC skipped open market operations again today for a net daily drain of CNY 100bln. (Newswires)

    PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2882 (Prev. 6.3072)

    New Zealand Employment Change (Q4) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 2.2%). (Newswires)

    New Zealand Employment Change (Q4) Y/Y 3.7% vs. Exp. 3.6% (Prev. 4.2%)

    New Zealand Unemployment Rate (Q4) 4.5% vs. Exp. 4.7% (Prev. 4.6%)

    CENTRAL BANKS

    Fed's Bostic (voter) said if robust growth and wage increases persist, we will see slow gradual rate hikes. (Newswires)

    ECB's Lautenschlaeger states that the ECB does not comment on individual fluctuations in the stock market. (Newswires)

    Spain has nominated Economy Minister Luis De Guindos for the role of Vice-President at the ECB. (Newswires)

    RBI kept rates unchanged as expected:

    Repo Rate: 6.00% vs Exp. 6.00%

    Reverse Repo Rate: 5.75% vs. Exp. 5.75%

    Cash Reserve Ratio: 4.00% vs. Exp. 4.00%

    EU/UK/US

    US House passed bill to fund government through to March 23rd via vote of 245 vs. 182, which sends the bill to the Senate. (Newswires)

    Germany's Conservatives and Social Democrats have agreed a coalition government deal. (SPD) In terms of personnel, Martin Schulz (SPD) has been appointed as Foreign Minister, Olaf Scholz (SPD) has been appointed as the Finance Minister with the Economy Ministry to go to the CDU.

    Goldman Sachs Chief Economist Hatzius still expects the Fed will hike 4 times this year, while he added that they haven't seen anything this year to change their view. (Newswires)

    European Commission reportedly wants the authority to punish UK non-compliance during the Brexit transition period by summarily blocking the UK's access to parts of the single market, according to a draft treaty. (FT) There were also separate reports that the UK could face a higher Brexit bill as EU is said to demand defence funding. (Newswires) Ireland is said to be pushing for a settled 'legal text' over Brexit border issue as early as next month, which reports add could derail Brexit negotiations. (Telegraph)

    EQUITIES

    European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.7%) are edging up this morning. US equity futures are pointing to a negative open on Wall Street, which has capped the upside this morning. European bourses are also failing to be excited by the reports of an agreement between the CDU, CSU and the SPD to form a grand coalition. In terms of stock specific movers, earnings continue to dictate price action with earnings from Rio Tinto (flat), ABN Amro (-2.7%), Sanofi (-1.8%). The healthcare sector will come into focus when GSK report their latest financial reports at midday.

    FX

    The Dollar is firmer against all G10 rivals apart from the Jpy, which has tested the resolve of bids at 109.00 again amidst more topside flow/heavy offers in Jpy crosses such as Eur/Jpy and Gbp/Jpy. However, the DXY has failed to sustain a rebound above near term resistance (89.600 treble top and then 89.700-750) or seriously challenge the next key tech levels above 90.000 (between 90.113-150). Hence, Wednesday could be key for the Buck in terms of whether its recent recovery continues or the end-2017 through January bear market resumes, and this also applies to Wall Street and equities in general after Monday’s rout and partial recovery yesterday. Looking at headline currency pairings, Eur/Usd is drifting lower having breached the 1.2400 level amidst conflicting headlines about a deal or no deal struck on a German grand coalition, but comfortably above the 20 DMA at 1.2303, while Cable has retreated further from 1.4000 and through a similar MA at 1.3958 to a 1.3920 low amidst reports that the EU will insist on harsh Brexit transition conditions if terms are violated. Usd/Cad remains anchored around 1.2500 after trade deficit misses on both side of the NA divide, while the Aud and Nzd are both hovering nearer recent lows around 0.7860 and 0.7300 respectively, with the Kiwi not getting much traction from better than expected NZ jobs data as attention quickly shifts to the RNBZ policy meeting later today.

    FIXED INCOME

    Little sign of any supply angst or auction hedging as core bonds continue to track the fortunes of equities in the main on an inverse-asset correlation basis. EU bourses have plateaued somewhat and debt futures are slowly clawing back declines made in anticipation of a more pronounced bounce, with Bunds actually trading just above parity at one stage (158.92 Eurex top, +6 ticks vs -29 ticks in early exchanges); no positive reaction to the solid Bund auction. Gilts have now crossed the water line at 121.97 vs Monday’s 121.93 Liffe settlement having been ¼ point adrift at worst, but remain conscious about the BoE (along with Brexit of course) as the MPC kicks off its first policy meet of 2018 today. USTs firmer and the curve fractionally flatter after a lacklustre start to this week’s refunding auctions, with 10 year notes to absorb and the yield around 2.76% within a 2.88%-2.68% rough range since last Friday’s strong US labour report. Note also, despite a light data docket there will be some attention on the latest Senate stop-gap funding vote on top of the stock vigil.

    COMMODITIES

    WTI and Brent crude futures are trending lower this morning, with the latter breaking below USD 67.00/bbls despite the last nights API crude inventory data showing an unexpected drawdown. Some of the bearish sentiment could be attributed to the latest EIA forecasts, in which the agency upped their US oil production led by shale to 11.2mln bpd in 2019 from 10.85mln bpd. In metals markets, spot gold is modestly higher whilst copper was supported during Asia-Pac trade amid the improved risk appetite.

PREVIEW: RBI expected to keep rates unchanged in policy announcement due at 0900GMT/0300CST
content:
The RBI is widely seen to keep rates unchanged when it conducts its bi-annual policy meeting today, with 14 out of 15 analysts surveyed forecasting the Repurchase Rate and Reverse Repo Rate to be maintained at 6.00% and 5.75% respectively, while 1 analyst is calling for a 25bps hike.

Aside from the near one-sided consensus for no policy changes, there are also increasing calls that the central bank may keep a neutral bias but provide a hawkish tone and some anticipate possible signals of future rate hikes. This follows a recent trend of firmer inflation data in which CPI rose to a 16-month high during December at 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 4.9%), which risks overshooting the central bank's medium-term target of 4% within a band of +/- 2 percentage points.

Recent increases in oil prices, coupled with the government’s vow to ensure a minimum support price of 50% greater than farmers’ cost of production and the likely impact this may have on food prices, would be another cause of concern for the RBI in its attempts to contain inflation and effectively narrows room for looser policy. In addition, the recent budget announcement to target fiscal deficit at 3.3% of GDP vs. Exp. 3.2% and the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act target of 3.0%, hints of a looser approach to government spending and suggests less urgency for RBI measures. 

External pressure for rate cuts also seems to have been somewhat alleviated as Indian Chief Economic Adviser Subramanian suggested that the scope for RBI rate cuts may be limited with growth picking up, which is in contrast to the usual comments from government officials who have on previous numerous occasions explicitly urged for rate cuts from the RBI. 

The announcement is scheduled for 0900GMT/0300CST and aside from the decision on rates, focus will be on the tone from the RBI and if expectations of a hawkish tone or signal for future hikes materializes. As a reminder, market reactions to the RBI are no so straight forward, as INR has previously been supported by dovish surprises which is due to increased expectations of foreign fund inflows spurred by the looser policy.

Recent comments and calls
- Barclays sees larger fiscal deficits and higher global commodity prices to possibly influence the MPC to adopt a cautious stance.
- BofAML expects a slightly hawkish pause, but says that inflation risks are overdone.
- ICICI Securities expects the RBI to be hawkish and also expects an upward revision to inflation forecasts.

content: The 10 year German debt future was marked down in line with US counterparts after Wall Street ended another wild session yesterday with recovery gains in the region of 1.75-2.6%, and thereby reclaiming around 50% of Monday’s heavy losses. The core Eurex bond opened at 158.58 vs the previous 158.86 close, but did not see any initial follow-through selling and subsequently ticked up to a 158.73 peak ahead of the EU cash bourse opens before fading again (just off a marginal new 158.57 base). As usual, very little reaction or attention paid to German ip data, but supply will be a factor for consideration given 10 year Bunds on offer ahead of the 2nd leg of US refunding and syndicated issuance from Finland and Belgium also in the pipeline. However, stock-watching remains the order of the day for fixed as market participants wait to see if this week’s sharp retracement is a correction or something more game-changing.

subject: DAILY BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: Supply today comes from Germany and the US
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: ECB 7-Day USD op

Previously the ECB allotted USD 39mln in its 7-day operation.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: Germany EUR 3bln 0.5% 2028 Bund Auction

IFR:

  • Sell off in EGB in Dec/Jan has provided a large concession
  • 10yr Bunds have underperformed on the German curve
  • 10yr Bunds are modestly cheaper compared to OATs and notably cheaper compared to peripherals
  • Lat three bund auctions have been technical failures

In terms of historical data, prev. b/c 1.13, average yield 0.54% and retention 19.5%.

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 24bln in new 10-year notes on 7 February at 1300 ET/1800 GMT

THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY:

The US Treasury will sell USD 68bln of new 3s (USD 28bln, Tuesday), new 10s (USD 24bln, Wednesday), and new 30s (USD 16bln, Thursday). With USD 46.6bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, net supply is seen at USD 21.4bln.

This month’s series of auctions comes at a key inflection point, with bonds selling-off aggressively at the beginning of the year. The 10-year note, for instance, has added c.40bps in 2018, a trend exacerbated by strong US data and hints that the Fed may lift rates more aggressively than anticipated.

10-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW:

Given the recent sell-off along the US curve, markets will be eyeing this week’s series of auctions to determine whether there is demand for US paper at these levels, or whether this week’s ‘stabilisation’ in yields portends a pause before another round of selling.

January’s 10-year note auction was received very well, with solid stop-through as well as cover above recent averages, and the high yield the largest since July 2014.  Fund takedown was the most since October, while foreign participation rose to the highest since March.

The latest positioning data shows dealers have raised positioning in the 7-11yr bucket to $2.1bln, the most since November.

Analysts at Societe Generale say that the 10-year note trades fair on asset swap when compared to the off-the-runs when viewed over the last two auction cycles, though trades cheap on the curve vs 5s and 30s. Meanwhile, the 2s10s spread has widened by over 10bps since the last auction cycle, and benchmark 10s are yielding more than the previous auction’s stop-out rate.

SocGen believes the 10s auction will benefit from cheap valuations, and we will likely see the largest stop-out rate at a 10s auction since January 2014. It also notes that the 10y benchmark is trading negative in repo, indicating the build-up of a short base, which could be a positive going into the auction.

Negatives, the bank argues, include the larger auction size, following the US Treasury’s recent Quarterly funding announcement, increased probability of more Fed rate hikes in 2018 following last week’s stellar Employment Situation Report, as well as compensation inflation picking up.

EQUITIES: SPX +1.75% at 2695, DJI +2.33% at 24912, NDX +2.6% at 6666

Top sectors: Materials +2.7%, Tech +2.7%, Cons Cyclicals +2.3%

Bottom sectors: Utilities -1.2%, Telecoms +0.45%, Energy +0.8%

A choppy session on Wall Street saw futures pare back their heavy losses incurred after yesterday’s sell-off, moving positive shortly after the NY cash equity open. Trade was choppy, but at the end of the day, the major indices were green.

Many have argued that Friday/Monday declines in stock prices were driven more by positioning and sentiment rather than underlying fundamentals, which still appear solid; US economic growth is firm, there are hints that inflation will return to target, and the US is near/in full employment (depending on who you ask).

More specific to equities, corporate earnings have grown this season, and some note that there is around $60bln of dividends to be paid over the course of February, which institutional investors will likely reinvest, supporting stocks. Further. The fiscal injection that the Trump administration will put behind infrastructure investment will likely support US companies.

There are also signs that the Treasury sell-off has stabilised for now, providing some comfort to those traders who sold stocks on the back of a sharp pick-up in yields.

Policymakers continue to ‘monitor’ markets: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that the recent volatility wasn’t enough to shake market fundamentals, the White House remains in monitoring mode, and the ECB has reached out to market participants.

Volatility, meanwhile, continues to be volatile (for want of a better phrase), as short vol trades continue to be crushed. The XIV was constantly being halted and then restarted through Tuesday trade. And though the VIX has eased off highs seen on Monday, it still remains near highs.

Finally, 10yr JGBs shrugged off the initial safe-haven outflows and returned flat, as price action proved to be as indecisive as the recovery in Japanese stocks. China reportedly deployed 300K troops along border with North Korea as preparation to deal with a crisis in the event of war breaking out. (Twitter)


US

The sheer magnitude of the equity price swings (and spike in volatility) seems to have put a pause in the unrelenting surge higher in US yields (and more crucially, real yields), and the tplex was happy to resume its role as a haven amid this week’s market turmoil. The curve bull flattened, and major spreads narrowed slightly. The US will auction $68bln in new 3s/10s/30s this week, and with $46.6bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, net supply is seen at $21.4bln. The issuance gives traders an opportunity to assess whether the bond market sell-off has stabilised, or whether there is still room to run. Today’s 3s auction will not have answered that question given the sale was lacklustre. The auction tailed, cover was a touch weaker (though above recent averages), with dealer takedown particularly noteworthy at 40.5%, above recent averages. US T-Note futures settle +7 ticks at 121-15+.

Fed's Bostic (voter) said if robust growth and wage increases persist, we will see slow gradual rate hikes. (Newswires)

US House passed bill to fund government through to March 23rd via vote of 245 vs. 182, which sends the bill to the Senate. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs Chief Economist Hatzius still expects the Fed will hike 4 times this year, while he added that they haven't seen anything this year to change their view. (Newswires)

China filed new challenges against US tariffs for solar panels and washing machines at WTO. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: RBI expected to keep rates unchanged in policy announcement due at 0900GMT/0300CST
content:
The RBI is widely seen to keep rates unchanged when it conducts its bi-annual policy meeting today, with 14 out of 15 analysts surveyed forecasting the Repurchase Rate and Reverse Repo Rate to be maintained at 6.00% and 5.75% respectively, while 1 analyst is calling for a 25bps hike.

Aside from the near one-sided consensus for no policy changes, there are also increasing calls that the central bank may keep a neutral bias but provide a hawkish tone and some anticipate possible signals of future rate hikes. This follows a recent trend of firmer inflation data in which CPI rose to a 16-month high during December at 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 4.9%), which risks overshooting the central bank's medium-term target of 4% within a band of +/- 2 percentage points.

Recent increases in oil prices, coupled with the government’s vow to ensure a minimum support price of 50% greater than farmers’ cost of production and the likely impact this may have on food prices, would be another cause of concern for the RBI in its attempts to contain inflation and effectively narrows room for looser policy. In addition, the recent budget announcement to target fiscal deficit at 3.3% of GDP vs. Exp. 3.2% and the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act target of 3.0%, hints of a looser approach to government spending and suggests less urgency for RBI measures. 

External pressure for rate cuts also seems to have been somewhat alleviated as Indian Chief Economic Adviser Subramanian suggested that the scope for RBI rate cuts may be limited with growth picking up, which is in contrast to the usual comments from government officials who have on previous numerous occasions explicitly urged for rate cuts from the RBI. 

The announcement is scheduled for 0900GMT/0300CST and aside from the decision on rates, focus will be on the tone from the RBI and if expectations of a hawkish tone or signal for future hikes materializes. As a reminder, market reactions to the RBI are no so straight forward, as INR has previously been supported by dovish surprises which is due to increased expectations of foreign fund inflows spurred by the looser policy.

Recent comments and calls
- Barclays sees larger fiscal deficits and higher global commodity prices to possibly influence the MPC to adopt a cautious stance.
- BofAML expects a slightly hawkish pause, but says that inflation risks are overdone.
- ICICI Securities expects the RBI to be hawkish and also expects an upward revision to inflation forecasts.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly higher with stock markets on rebound mode
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as region mirrors the rebound on Wall St. where stocks found reprieve from the 2-day market turmoil. Furthermore, the turnaround was attributed to dip buying amidst the backdrop of continued strong economic fundamentals, which saw S&P 500 briefly reclaim 2700 and the DJIA home in on the 25000 level. ASX 200 (+1.1%) trades positive with energy and resource names leading the recovery as commodities nurse losses, while Nikkei 225 (+2.7%) is the best performer on a weaker currency and has clawed back the majority of the prior day’s near-5% decline. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) are also higher as nearly all bourses are lifted by the rising tide, aside from New Zealand which gets its first opportunity to digest the prior day’s sell-off on return from holiday.

FX markets are relatively range-bound overnight with most majors holding on to recent gains against the USD, although JPY was an exception with the safe-haven subdued amid the improvement in risk appetite. Elsewhere, NZD/USD was underpinned after strong jobs data in which Employment Change topped estimates and the Unemployment Rate unexpectedly declined, while the PBoC was also a hindrance on the greenback after it set the strongest fix since August 2015.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are weaker on safe-haven outflows and amid similar declines in USTs, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement failed to spur any market reaction as the bank kept amounts inline with the previous.
